summary: It's unfair how Daenerys is held to higher standards and judgedfar harsher than any other character by a large amount of the...
body: It’s unfair how Daenerys is held to higher standards and judgedfar harsher than any other character by a large amount of the fandom. Like, any other character is allowed to make mistakes or have flaws-and they are considered to be realistic because of these things. But then moment Dany does anything even slightly wrong or is shown to be anything less than flawless everyone is on her neck for being “evil”. On a show where male characters can murder or attempt to kill children and yet remain fav favourites Daenerys is the one who gets the most hate. The woman who stop pursuing her livelong mission of taking back the Iron Throne in order to save all the people in Westeros. Imagine hating humanity’s savior. And the funniest thing about all those who hate her is that in the end thanks to Dany and her personal sacrifices their favourites will live to see another day. But will they be grateful to Dany about it? Hell, no! They will find a minor detail to bitch about her.

title: All in the family
body:

Meanwhile in the Godswood..

trail.content:

Meanwhile in the Godswood..

body:
Daenerys Vs Sansa Bullshit.

I have never been a huge fan of book or show Sansa. That being said she’s grown a lot in the last three seasons and I can respect/relate to that. I can see why so many people adore her. She’s like a Disney princess in this horrible world, smart on the sly but always the lady, comes from the seemingly perfect family, is abused mentally/physically and later sexually and raises herself back up.

There’s some that say she wouldn’t be where she is without Jon and this is partly true. If Jon wasn’t the Lord commander of the nights watch Sansa would’ve had no refuge. If Jon didn’t agree to go to battle with Ramsay they wouldn’t of gotten winterfell back, he wouldn’t of become king and she wouldn’t of been named Lady when he left.

But she has to be mentally strong and cunning to leave Ramsay/go to battle against him, to kill Littlefinger and she also has to be gentle, kind and considerate to be the Lady. But she’s also undoubtedly flawed. She disliked and picked on Arya as a child because she wasn’t graceful or pretty. She alienated Jon because he was a bastard. She was disgusted by Tyrion because he was a dwarf. She was self centred and selfish and I expect book Sansa is still in many ways the same in her inner thoughts. So many of us as children were the exact same. Some of us still are.

Daenerys had the opposite as a child. She resonates with those of us who didn’t have the best upbringing. She was the underdog. Nobody expected much of her. But here this girl who was physically/mentally and sexually abused, hidden away, lied to and sold has made herself into a queen. Not just any queen but the queen she’s always imagined.

She’s between Visenya and Rhaenys, she can be the lady but she can also be dark. Some people claim she had everything handed to her because she was given dragons eggs and the dragons are the reason she’s been able to rise. This is partly true. If she didn’t have the newborn dragons she wouldn’t have been permitted to enter Quarth and thus died in the red waste. The dragons have given her an edge nobody else has, they’re her strongest weapon and the reason why she could free slaves, conquer cities ect.

But think about if Viserys had the dragons. He would either have been murdered very early on for gloating/showing off or set the dragons on the world to cause chaos. She’s smart and calculated. In the book someone gifts her some armour that wouldn’t be any good in a real battle we’re told through her thoughts she has proper armour should battle come. She’s not afraid to get her hands dirty and she takes responsibility for her mistakes.

That being said she’s also undoubtedly flawed. She’s headstrong, her first thought when attacked is to kill, she sometimes struggles to see past her own experiences and feelings and thinks others who have been in these situations should feel the same.

Sansa’s flaws are a product of her environment and upbringing. Daenerys’s flaws are a product of her environment and upbringing. This doesn’t make either character bad, evil, horrible ect.

My point is that while these two characters are very different they are also very much alike. It would make zero sense for these two to become enemies so why do we pit them against each other? Why are we desperate for a woman vs woman? Why do we have to use a man to get that? Why does one have to be better than the other? Simple, they don’t.

Grey characters are the best characters. Those are the characters we can cry with, laugh with, root for, fear for. Stop trying to make them perfect and embrace their imperfections.

tags: i won't stand for slander! (or libel rather)
summary: You've expressed disdain over Rhaenys-Corlys and Rhaegar-Lyanna (and understandably so) because the girls were teens and the men...
question: You've expressed disdain over Rhaenys-Corlys and Rhaegar-Lyanna (and understandably so) because the girls were teens and the men adults, but you're pretty OK with Daenerys-Maron, even though she was 15 and he was in his mid-thirties (the same age as her brother). I am not attacking you, just curius - what's the difference?
answer:
For the record, I don’t only despise Rhaenys-Corlys and Rhaegar-Lyanna because of their ages, though that is obviously a main factor. I also despise them because of their actions (Maron’s, or lack thereof, are discussed below) and the power imbalance. Rhaenys was granddaughter of a king, yes, but Corlys had literally a generation’s worth of experience on her and since their marriage was a ~love match~ yet Rhaenys was married at just 16, that means he groomed, and lusted after, a CHILD. The imbalance, minus the grooming part, is even more pronounced in Rhaegar-Lyanna, but I’ve gone over that at length before.

Now, for the rest:

Never once are we told Maron’s age, for starters. Mariah was likely born in 154, given that she and Daeron were decreed to wed “when they were of age,” which is 16, and since Daeron was 17 at the time of his marriage, that would imply Mariah was a year younger. I personally peg Maron being born in 165-167, which would put him at 21-23 at the time of his marriage, 5-7 years older than Daenerys. My supposition is that there was at least one child born between Mariah and Maron who died in infancy or childhood.

In fact, the Prince of Dorne and his consort having at least one child between Mariah and Maron is likely. Why on earth would he agree to marry off one of his two children away so early? Why would he make the gamble that Maron would not only survive childhood but have a fruitful marriage to a woman yet to be decided? Why is it not much more probable that he had at least two other children besides Mariah, thus being more confident that her being married to the Targs wouldn’t be detrimental to his succession?

We are told Mariah and Daeron were children when their father made the treaty with Baelor, which allows for a wide range of ages, up to the age of 16. Cases in point: Ned refers to Lyanna as a “child-woman” at 16, Kevan refers to Jeyne Westerling as a child at 16 (and Tyrion repeats this), Yandel and others in Casterly Rock refer to 10-year-old Tywin as a child, etc.

And again, “of age” in this series is said to be 16, meaning anything younger than that would be considered a child. In other words, it would be perfectly reasonable for the treaty to have been done when Maron was an infant and Mariah around 13.

Secondly, there’s a math error in the world book (one of many) wrt Daenerys’s age, because she’s said to have been married “once she was of age,” so 16, but also said to have been born two years after Daemon Blackfyre, who was born in 170, which would put her at 15. I choose to take the former as fact.

Thirdly, Maron barely knew Daenerys, and their marriage was arranged. It was nothing like the Corlys-Rhaenys situation.

Fourthly, he treated her astronomically well, to the point of building her a PALACE ffs. He never cheated on her, and they clearly had a lovely marriage, considering they had multiple children, she adored the Water Gardens wherein she started the tradition of children of all classes coming together, a portrait was commissioned of her that still hangs there today, etc.

Additionally, Maron is clearly contrasted with Daemon Blackfyre: Daemon claimed to have loved Daenerys, despite having 9+ children with Rohanne, meaning he had no qualms about not only egregiously insulting said wife, but Daenerys herself. Too, that he held no regard for established rule of law–he wanted to marry Daenerys while still married to Rohanne, despite polygamy being outlawed and its last practicer being Maegor the Cruel. For Daenerys’s part specifically, she “left no trace” of anything regarding Daemon, implying she was more than content in her own marriage.

So. In conclusion, there is a WORLD of difference between Maron-Daenerys and those other pairs.

Never once are we told Maron’s age, for starters. Mariah was likely born in 154, given that she and Daeron were decreed to wed “when they were of age,” which is 16, and since Daeron was 17 at the time of his marriage, that would imply Mariah was a year younger. I personally peg Maron being born in 165-167, which would put him at 21-23 at the time of his marriage, 5-7 years older than Daenerys. My supposition is that there was at least one child born between Mariah and Maron who died in infancy or childhood.

In fact, the Prince of Dorne and his consort having at least one child between Mariah and Maron is likely. Why on earth would he agree to marry off one of his two children away so early? Why would he make the gamble that Maron would not only survive childhood but have a fruitful marriage to a woman yet to be decided? Why is it not much more probable that he had at least two other children besides Mariah, thus being more confident that her being married to the Targs wouldn’t be detrimental to his succession?

We are told Mariah and Daeron were children when their father made the treaty with Baelor, which allows for a wide range of ages, up to the age of 16. Cases in point: Ned refers to Lyanna as a “child-woman” at 16, Kevan refers to Jeyne Westerling as a child at 16 (and Tyrion repeats this), Yandel and others in Casterly Rock refer to 10-year-old Tywin as a child, etc.

And again, “of age” in this series is said to be 16, meaning anything younger than that would be considered a child. In other words, it would be perfectly reasonable for the treaty to have been done when Maron was an infant and Mariah around 13.

Secondly, there’s a math error in the world book (one of many) wrt Daenerys’s age, because she’s said to have been married “once she was of age,” so 16, but also said to have been born two years after Daemon Blackfyre, who was born in 170, which would put her at 15. I choose to take the former as fact.

Thirdly, Maron barely knew Daenerys, and their marriage was arranged. It was nothing like the Corlys-Rhaenys situation.

Fourthly, he treated her astronomically well, to the point of building her a PALACE ffs. He never cheated on her, and they clearly had a lovely marriage, considering they had multiple children, she adored the Water Gardens wherein she started the tradition of children of all classes coming together, a portrait was commissioned of her that still hangs there today, etc.

Additionally, Maron is clearly contrasted with Daemon Blackfyre: Daemon claimed to have loved Daenerys, despite having 9+ children with Rohanne, meaning he had no qualms about not only egregiously insulting said wife, but Daenerys herself. Too, that he held no regard for established rule of law–he wanted to marry Daenerys while still married to Rohanne, despite polygamy being outlawed and its last practicer being Maegor the Cruel. For Daenerys’s part specifically, she “left no trace” of anything regarding Daemon, implying she was more than content in her own marriage.

So. In conclusion, there is a WORLD of difference between Maron-Daenerys and those other pairs.
trail.content:
For the record, I don’t only despise Rhaenys-Corlys and Rhaegar-Lyanna because of their ages, though that is obviously a main factor. I also despise them because of their actions (Maron’s, or lack thereof, are discussed below) and the power imbalance. Rhaenys was granddaughter of a king, yes, but Corlys had literally a generation’s worth of experience on her and since their marriage was a ~love match~ yet Rhaenys was married at just 16, that means he groomed, and lusted after, a CHILD. The imbalance, minus the grooming part, is even more pronounced in Rhaegar-Lyanna, but I’ve gone over that at length before.

Now, for the rest:

Never once are we told Maron’s age, for starters. Mariah was likely born in 154, given that she and Daeron were decreed to wed “when they were of age,” which is 16, and since Daeron was 17 at the time of his marriage, that would imply Mariah was a year younger. I personally peg Maron being born in 165-167, which would put him at 21-23 at the time of his marriage, 5-7 years older than Daenerys. My supposition is that there was at least one child born between Mariah and Maron who died in infancy or childhood.

In fact, the Prince of Dorne and his consort having at least one child between Mariah and Maron is likely. Why on earth would he agree to marry off one of his two children away so early? Why would he make the gamble that Maron would not only survive childhood but have a fruitful marriage to a woman yet to be decided? Why is it not much more probable that he had at least two other children besides Mariah, thus being more confident that her being married to the Targs wouldn’t be detrimental to his succession?

We are told Mariah and Daeron were children when their father made the treaty with Baelor, which allows for a wide range of ages, up to the age of 16. Cases in point: Ned refers to Lyanna as a “child-woman” at 16, Kevan refers to Jeyne Westerling as a child at 16 (and Tyrion repeats this), Yandel and others in Casterly Rock refer to 10-year-old Tywin as a child, etc.

And again, “of age” in this series is said to be 16, meaning anything younger than that would be considered a child. In other words, it would be perfectly reasonable for the treaty to have been done when Maron was an infant and Mariah around 13.

Secondly, there’s a math error in the world book (one of many) wrt Daenerys’s age, because she’s said to have been married “once she was of age,” so 16, but also said to have been born two years after Daemon Blackfyre, who was born in 170, which would put her at 15. I choose to take the former as fact.

Thirdly, Maron barely knew Daenerys, and their marriage was arranged. It was nothing like the Corlys-Rhaenys situation.

Fourthly, he treated her astronomically well, to the point of building her a PALACE ffs. He never cheated on her, and they clearly had a lovely marriage, considering they had multiple children, she adored the Water Gardens wherein she started the tradition of children of all classes coming together, a portrait was commissioned of her that still hangs there today, etc.

Additionally, Maron is clearly contrasted with Daemon Blackfyre: Daemon claimed to have loved Daenerys, despite having 9+ children with Rohanne, meaning he had no qualms about not only egregiously insulting said wife, but Daenerys herself. Too, that he held no regard for established rule of law–he wanted to marry Daenerys while still married to Rohanne, despite polygamy being outlawed and its last practicer being Maegor the Cruel. For Daenerys’s part specifically, she “left no trace” of anything regarding Daemon, implying she was more than content in her own marriage.

So. In conclusion, there is a WORLD of difference between Maron-Daenerys and those other pairs.
